conclusion: The problem involves determining how the shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves to the back-left above the objects.
Shadows always fall away from the light source, meaning their positions shift in the opposite direction of the light's movement.
When the light source moves higher, farther back, and to the left, all shadows will generally shift forward and to the right on the floor plane.
Shadow A, cast by the white cloth, will appear in front of the cloth and slightly to the viewer's right.
Shadow B, cast by the table mirror, will shift to the mirror's front-right, with its stem and head still projecting a compact, oval-ish shadow displaced forward-right.
Shadow C, cast by the metal ring, will retain its circular shape but will be translated forward-right of the ring.
Shadow D, cast by the avocado, will move forward-right of the fruit, retaining its small, pear-shaped patch.
After the light source is relocated to the back-left, all four shadows (A, B, C, and D) will migrate to the front-right of their respective objects while retaining their individual shapes.
